definition: to impede/to obstruct/to hold back
to drag/to tow/to trail/to hang down/to mop (the floor)/to delay/to drag on
variant of 拖[tuo1]
empress/queen/(archaic) monarch/ruler
back/behind/rear/afterwards/after/later/post-
surname Hou
leg/CL:條|条[tiao2]
hip bone/old variant of 腿[tui3]

sentences.english: There is a dark side to the progress principle.
sentences.chinese: 在这个进程原则中有一个拖后腿的因素。

sentences.english: But compared to museums and libraries, universities will continue to drag their feet.
sentences.chinese: 但和博物馆和图书馆相比，大学仍然拖后腿。

sentences.english: Can your biorhythms actually make or break your career?
sentences.chinese: 你的生物钟真的能帮助你的工作或者拖后腿吗？

definition: to be a drag or hindrance on sb
to encumber/to be a burden on/to implicate
to do less well than before/to make a concession/setback/backward step/leeway/room to maneuver/fallback
lame (unimpressive)/a huge letdown/not to try at all
passing line or score (in an examination)
to buy soy sauce/it's none of my business ("I’m just here to buy some soy sauce")
one's bicycle chain comes off/(fig.) to let sb down/to drop the ball/to screw up
to fall behind/to drop out
to be more of a hindrance than a help
to pass an exam or a test/to meet a minimum standard
(slang) (neologism derived from 背黑鍋|背黑锅[bei1 hei1 guo1]) to carry the can/to be a scapegoat
(jocularly) to be under great pressure (a pun on 亞歷山大|亚历山大[Ya4 li4 shan1 da4])
to suffer losses/to come to grief/to lose out/to get the worst of it/to be at a disadvantage/unfortunately
disparity/gap
to fail/to flunk
to overtake
